para.paratext: In Addington v. Texas,[1] the United States Supreme Court held that the standard of proof in a commitment for mental illness must be greater than the preponderance of evidence to meet due process standards, but need not reach the beyond a reasonable doubt standard. The Court approved a “clear and convincing evidence” standard but stated that each state could adopt a higher standard.

O.C.G.A. § 37-3-1(8) establishes the standard of proof in termination of parental rights cases as “clear and convincing evidence.” In Santosky v. Kramer,[2] the United States Supreme Court held that due process required “clear and convincing evidence” to sever parental rights and that the “fair preponderance of the evidence” standard denied due process. In re Suggs[3] involved the Georgia statute. The Georgia Supreme Court held that the Georgia statute satisfied Santosky v. Kramer's “clear and convincing” requirement.

In Blackburn v. Blackburn,[4] the Georgia Supreme Court cited Santosky when considering the standard to apply on appellate review. The Court of Appeals had denied a discretionary appeal and the Georgia Supreme Court granted certiorari and reversed. The court held that the “reasonable evidence” standard was not enough and stated: “We hold that the appropriate standard of appellate review in a case where a parent's rights to his child have been severed is ‘whether after reviewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the appellee, any rational trier of fact could have found by clear and convincing evidence that the natural parent's rights to custody have been lost.’”

In the case of In re R. L. Y.,[5] the order of the trial judge in a parental termination case did not clearly state that he had applied the standard of “clear and convincing evidence,” so the case was remanded for further findings.

In Clark v. Wade,[6] the Georgia Supreme Court extended the “clear and convincing” standard to custody disputes between parents and third parties just as it applies in termination cases. Thus, “a third-party relative may overcome the statutory presumption in favor of parental custody only by presenting clear and convincing evidence that the award of custody to the parent is not in the best interest of the child.”[7] The court reasoned that the importance of the individual interests involved and the significance of the parent-child relationship warranted the higher standard of proof. The standard also applies to the termination of parental rights conducted as part of adoption proceedings,[8] and to cases granting grandparent visitation rights. In the latter, the Court first struck down as unconstitutional the Grandparent's Visitation Act of 1988, reasoning that the Act authorized courts to award visitation to grandparents over the objection of a fit parent without a clear and convincing showing of harm to the child.[9] Subsequently, the General Assembly enacted the Grandparent Visitation Act of 2012, which the Georgia Supreme Court likewise reasoned allowed a court to grant visitation under some circumstances over the objection of fit parents without a clear and convincing showing of harm to the child. Thus, the Court struck down O.C.G.A. § 19-7-3(d) as unconstitutional.[10]

O.C.G.A. § 31-20-3 also uses the “clear and convincing” proof standard in cases involving involuntary sterilization. Motes v. Hall County Dept. of Family and Children Services[11] held that under Santosky this is the proper standard.

The Santosky v. Kramer[12] standard of “clear and convincing evidence” has also been adopted as the applicable standard for an award of punitive damages in tort cases under O.C.G.A. § 51-12-5.1(b), which states that punitive damages can be awarded only if a plaintiff proves “by clear and convincing evidence that the defendant's actions showed willful misconduct, malice, fraud, wantonness, oppression, or … conscious indifference to consequences.”

Moreover, clear and convincing evidence is the standard that a plaintiff must bear when proving actual fraud.[13] It is also the required standard of proof that a ward must meet when attempting to modify his conservatorship.[14]

In Clarke v. Cotton,[15] the Court of Appeals, affirming the trial court's award of punitive damages received by the plaintiff in a motor vehicle collision, stated that “‘clear and convincing evidence’ is considered in this state to be an ‘intermediate standard of proof’ … which is greater than the preponderance of the evidence standard ordinarily employed in civil proceedings, but less than the reasonable doubt standard applicable in criminal proceedings.”

In a case involving a post-collision fuel-fed fire, the Georgia Court of Appeals held that the trial court erred by refusing to define the “clear and convincing evidence” standard of proof required for punitive damages.[16] In fact, an award of punitive damages may be reversed when no instruction is given which defines the “clear and convincing evidence” necessary to award those damages. The trial court is obligated to define this standard of proof “even in the absence of a request to charge.”[17] The Georgia Suggested Pattern Jury Instructions define “clear and convincing” evidence as:

evidence that will cause the jury to firmly believe each essential element of the claim to a high degree of probability. Proof by clear and convincing evidence requires a level of proof greater than a preponderance of the evidence (but less than beyond a reasonable doubt).[18]
Judge Jackson's special concurrence in Clarke v. Cotton[19] also contains a variety of definitions of clear and convincing evidence.
In order for a public figure to recover in a suit for defamation, there must be proof by clear and convincing evidence of actual malice on the part of the defendant.[20]
Addington v. Texas, 441 U.S. 418, 99 S. Ct. 1804, 60 L. Ed. 2d 323 (1979).
Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 102 S. Ct. 1388, 71 L. Ed. 2d 599 (1982).

In Rivera v. Minnich, 483 U.S. 574, 107 S. Ct. 3001, 97 L. Ed. 2d 473 (1987), the court considered Santosky v. Kramer and agreed that the standard of “clear and convincing evidence” was required to sever parental rights. However, the court held that the standard of the preponderance of evidence was all that due process required in a paternity proceeding.

O.C.G.A. § 15-11-94(a) provides that the standard of proof for the juvenile court to terminate parental rights is by clear and convincing evidence; In re M.M.M.T., 327 Ga. App. 572, 760 S.E.2d 188 (2014).

Blackburn v. Blackburn, 249 Ga. 689, 292 S.E.2d 821 (1982); In In Interest of H.L.T., 164 Ga. App. 517, 298 S.E.2d 33 (1982); White v. Department of Human Resources, 167 Ga. App. 731, 307 S.E.2d 686 (1983).

In 1996, the Georgia General Assembly enacted the parent-third-party custody statute, O.C.G.A. § 19-7-1(b.1), which governs custody disputes between a biological parent and third parties seeking custody of a child. The statute “establishes a rebuttable presumption that parental custody is always in the child's best interest, thus favoring the biological parent over the third party.” Clark v. Wade, 273 Ga. 587, 590, 544 S.E.2d 99 (2001).

In Burke v. King, 254 Ga. App. 351, 352–353, 562 S.E.2d 271 (2002), the Georgia Court of Appeals has recognized that “[i]mplicit in this statute are three presumptions: (1) the parent is a fit person entitled to custody, (2) a fit parent acts in the best interest of his or her child, and (3) the child's best interest is to be in the custody of a parent. To overcome the statutory presumption in favor of parental custody, the third-party relative ‘must prove by clear and convincing evidence that the child will suffer physical or emotional harm if custody were awarded to the biological parent.’” Burke v. King, 254 Ga. App. 351, 352–353, 562 S.E.2d 271 (2002) (quoting Clark v. Wade, 273 Ga. 587, 544 S.E.2d 99 (2001)).
